Detailed Description

Portable signal handling.

Author:
Marc Dubreuil, Christian Gagne and Marc Parizeau, Laboratoire de vision et systèmes numériques, Université Laval

This class can be used to handle common signals. To define custom handlers, it should be subclassed and virtual method SignalHandler::main should be overloaded. For example, the following code snippet defines a custom handler for signal SignalType::eSigInt (Ctl-C): 

class SigIntHandler : public SignalHandler {
 public:
    SigIntHandler(void) {setCustomAction(eSigInt);}

    virtual void main(SignalType inType) {
        switch(inType) {
           case eSigInt: 
             cout << "My custom handler!" << endl;
             exit(-1);
           default:
             cout << "Unsupported signal!" << endl;
             break;
        }
	}
};

Furthermore, for each signal type, a stack of actions can be managed using methods SignalHandler::pushAction and SignalHandler::popAction.

Definition at line 74 of file SignalHandler.hpp.

Member Enumeration Documentation

enum PACC::SignalHandler::SignalType

Enumeration of supported signal types.

Enumerator:
eSigAbrt 

Abort (ANSI).

eSigFPE 

Floating-point exception (ANSI).

eSigIll 

Illegal instruction (ANSI).

eSigInt 

Interrupt (ANSI).

eSigSegV 

Segmentation violation (ANSI).

eSigTerm 

Termination (ANSI).

eSigAlrm 

Alarm clock (POSIX).

eSigChld 

Child status has changed (POSIX).

eSigCont 

Continue (POSIX).

eSigHUp 

Hangup (POSIX).

eSigKill 

Kill, unblockable (POSIX).

eSigPipe 

Broken pipe (POSIX).

eSigQuit 

Quit (POSIX).

eSigStop 

Stop, unblockable (POSIX).

eSigTStp 

Keyboard stop (POSIX).

eSigTrap 

Trace trap (POSIX).

eSigTTin 

Background read from tty (POSIX).

eSigTTou 

Background write to tty (POSIX).

eSigUsr1 

User-defined signal 1 (POSIX).

eSigUsr2 

User-defined signal 2 (POSIX).

virtual void PACC::SignalHandler::main ( SignalType  inType  )  [pure virtual]

Main function of signal handler.

This pure virtual method must be overloaded in a subclass in order to define custom signal actions. Argument inType specifies the signal type that must be processed for the current pending signal.

void SignalHandler::popAction ( SignalHandler::SignalType  inType  )  [static]

Pop previous action for signals of type inType.

This method pops the top element of the action stack and resets to the previous action. It is an error to call this method when the stack is empty. Note that, for any given signal, the first call to one of the set methods (SignalHandler::setCustomAction, SignalHandler::setDefaultAction, or SignalHandler::setIgnoreAction) executes an implicit push of the previous action. A call to this method in that particular situation will thus restore this previous action (usually the default system action).

Exceptions:
runtime_error This method throws an exception if called for an unsuported signal. Note that Windows only supports ANSI signals (see SignalHandler::SignalType).

00149     if(smActions[inType].top().mHandler == 0) {
00150         // action must be external function
00151         lFunc = ::signal(lSignal, smActions[inType].top().mFunc);
00152     } else {
00153         // action is custom
00154         lFunc = ::signal(lSignal, runAction);
00155     }
00156     PACC_AssertM(lFunc != SIG_ERR, "popAction() internal error: invalid signal") 
00157 }

void SignalHandler::pushAction ( SignalHandler::SignalType  inType  )  [static]

Push current action for signals of type inType.

This method pushes a copy of the current action onto the action stack. It is an error to call this method prior to setting a first action using either SignalHandler::setCustomAction, SignalHandler::SetDefaultAction, or SignalHandler::setIgnoreAction.

Definition at line 162 of file SignalHandler.cpp.

00163 {
00164     PACC_AssertM(!smActions[inType].empty(), "pushAction() stack is empty, set an action first!");
00165     smActions[inType].push(smActions[inType].top());
00166 }

void SignalHandler::setCustomAction ( SignalHandler::SignalType  inType  ) 

Make this signal handler process future signals of type inType.

When called with an empty action stack, the later is initialized by making an implicit push of the previous action. Otherwise, it does not affect the action stack.

Exceptions:
runtime_error This method throws an exception if called for an unsuported signal. Note that Windows only supports ANSI signals (see SignalHandler::SignalType).

Definition at line 184 of file SignalHandler.cpp.

00185 {
00186     // set new action
00187     int lSignal = convertToNativeSignal(inType);
00188     HandlerPointer lFunc = ::signal(lSignal, runAction);
00189     PACC_AssertM(lFunc != SIG_ERR, "setCustomAction() internal error: invalid signal");
00190     // update action stack
00191     Action lCustom(this, 0);
00192     if(smActions[inType].empty()) {
00193         // initialize the action stack
00194         smActions[inType].push(Action(0, lFunc));
00195         smActions[inType].push(lCustom);
00196     } else {
00197         // overwrite the top action
00198         smActions[inType].top() = lCustom;
00199     }
00200 }

void SignalHandler::setDefaultAction ( SignalHandler::SignalType  inType  )  [static]

Make the default system action process future signals of type inType.

When called with an empty action stack, the later is initialized by making an implicit push of the previous action. Otherwise, it does not affect the action stack.

Exceptions:
runtime_error This method throws an exception if called for an unsuported signal. Note that Windows only supports ANSI signals (see SignalHandler::SignalType).

void SignalHandler::setIgnoreAction ( SignalHandler::SignalType  inType  )  [static]

Specifies that future signals of type inType should be ignored.

When called with an empty action stack, the later is initialized by making an implicit push of the previous action. Otherwise, it does not affect the action stack.

Exceptions:
runtime_error This method throws an exception if called for an unsuported signal. Note that Windows only supports ANSI signals (see SignalHandler::SignalType).
